quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: In our conversation, Paul shares some amazing stories of failure, including the story of him giving a huge presentation where he froze on stage and had to walk off.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: Highlights a concrete failure scenario that sets up practical lessons on handling high-stakes mistakes and learning from them.

quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: We then get deep into how to think about AI as a part of your product strategy, including a ton of great examples from Intercom's experience going all in on AI.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: Signals an actionable strategic theme—treating AI as a core product strategy component—grounded in real company examples.

quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: Paul also shares some of his favorite frameworks, and product lessons, and so much more.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: Points to the presence of reusable frameworks and lessons practitioners can apply, even though the specific frameworks aren’t in this segment.

quotes.topic_title: Cannes keynote freeze and recovery
quotes.text: I think you have to go with it with these things, when life throws you these, whatever, curveballs you have got to adapt and it's not that big a deal.
quotes.speaker: Paul Adams
quotes.context: A practical resilience mindset: adapt in the moment and keep perspective when things go wrong publicly.

quotes.topic_title: Cannes keynote freeze and recovery
quotes.text: None of these things are that big a deal, at the end of the day. You move on and live and learn.
quotes.speaker: Paul Adams
quotes.context: A memorable reframing that reduces fear of failure and encourages iterative learning after setbacks.

quotes.topic_title: Cannes keynote freeze and recovery
quotes.text: I just froze. I couldn't remember what I was supposed to say. It was the first ever time in my life I'd rehearsed the talk word for word.
quotes.speaker: Paul Adams
quotes.context: A counterintuitive lesson that over-scripted, word-for-word rehearsal can backfire under pressure versus flexible talking points.

quotes.topic_title: Cannes keynote freeze and recovery
quotes.text: But, I managed to turn it around, I walked back out. I'd been disarmed internally in my head.
quotes.speaker: Paul Adams
quotes.context: A concrete example of recovery after a failure moment—reset internally, then re-engage to finish strong.

quotes.topic_title: Cannes keynote freeze and recovery
quotes.text: You can turn it around. Yeah.
quotes.speaker: Paul Adams
quotes.context: A succinct, practitioner-relevant takeaway: even worst-case public speaking failures can be recovered from in real time.

quotes.topic_title: Google social product failures and fear-driven strategy
quotes.text: I think, a lot of the motivation for those projects came from a place of fear. It didn't come from a place of, "Let's make a great product for people. Let's really understand the things people struggle with when communicating with family and friends. Let's really, really try and create something wonderful." It came from a place of fear.
quotes.speaker: Paul Adams
quotes.context: A clear warning that strategy driven by competitive fear (vs. user value) leads teams toward the wrong product decisions.

quotes.topic_title: Google social product failures and fear-driven strategy
quotes.text: And by the way, I should say, at the time in Google, there was other things happening that were amazing, like Google were building Google Maps, an incredible product. One of my favorite products. I think one of the best products ever made. They were building Android.
quotes.speaker: Paul Adams
quotes.context: A concrete contrast showing the same company can produce world-class products when oriented around genuine user value, not fear.

quotes.topic_title: Google social product failures and fear-driven strategy
quotes.text: And so, what we used to do is, what I used to do with people was map out their social network, all the people in it, their family, their friends, how they communicate. We'd map on all the channels, we'd talk about what worked well, what didn't.
quotes.speaker: Paul Adams
quotes.context: A practical research method practitioners can copy: mapping real user networks and channels to uncover communication needs.

quotes.topic_title: Google social product failures and fear-driven strategy
quotes.text: And the same pattern emerged every single time, which was, people need way better ways to communicate with small groups of family and friends.
quotes.speaker: Paul Adams
quotes.context: A repeatable insight from longitudinal research that points to small-group communication as a core user problem worth building around.

quotes.topic_title: Google social product failures and fear-driven strategy
quotes.text: Facebook was an amazing place at the time and exciting. And they were trying to do things for the other reasons, the good reasons. "Okay, let's build an amazing product for people."
quotes.speaker: Paul Adams
quotes.context: A succinct product principle: anchor strategy in building for users rather than reacting to competitors.

quotes.topic_title: Leaving Google for Facebook amid scrutiny
quotes.text: But things like, everyone worked in Google Plus was sent to a different building. That building had a different key card. If you didn't work in Google Plus you could not get in.
quotes.speaker: Paul Adams
quotes.context: A concrete example of extreme internal secrecy that can reshape culture and collaboration dynamics.

quotes.topic_title: Leaving Google for Facebook amid scrutiny
quotes.text: And, as a result, there was a lot of antagonism internally for Google Plus.
quotes.speaker: Paul Adams
quotes.context: Highlights a counterintuitive consequence of heavy confidentiality: it can create internal resentment and friction.

quotes.topic_title: Leaving Google for Facebook amid scrutiny
quotes.text: Yeah, when I left, Google assumed that I was one of the spies. I was quarantined. I told them I was leaving. They forensically analyzed my laptop, all sorts of stuff like that.
quotes.speaker: Paul Adams
quotes.context: A vivid operational detail showing how competitive dynamics can escalate into intense security processes that affect people and teams.

quotes.topic_title: Leaving Google for Facebook amid scrutiny
quotes.text: But the root cause for me is that the project has been run from a place of competitive fear, which I don't think leads to good things.
quotes.speaker: Paul Adams
quotes.context: A memorable mental model for diagnosing unhealthy product strategy: fear-driven competition tends to produce poor outcomes.

quotes.topic_title: Why failure matters and Intercom’s ship-to-learn culture
quotes.text: At Facebook, you can design the product. But at Intercom, you can design the company.
quotes.speaker: Paul Adams
quotes.context: A memorable reframing of career and leadership impact—from shaping features to shaping the entire system (culture, principles, how work gets done).

quotes.topic_title: Why failure matters and Intercom’s ship-to-learn culture
quotes.text: I'm a big believer in big bets, high risk, high reward.
quotes.speaker: Paul Adams
quotes.context: A clear strategic stance that encourages practitioners to prioritize outsized opportunities over safer incrementalism when aiming for step-change outcomes.

quotes.topic_title: Why failure matters and Intercom’s ship-to-learn culture
quotes.text: And if you make big bets, you're going to get a lot of it wrong.
quotes.speaker: Paul Adams
quotes.context: Normalizes failure as an expected input to ambitious strategy, helping teams plan for iteration rather than perfection.

quotes.topic_title: Why failure matters and Intercom’s ship-to-learn culture
quotes.text: Ship fast, ship early, ship often.
quotes.speaker: Paul Adams
quotes.context: A simple operating principle teams can adopt to shorten feedback loops and accelerate learning and course-correction.

quotes.topic_title: Why failure matters and Intercom’s ship-to-learn culture
quotes.text: So there's a real tension there, a real trade-off, where people have these high standards, which we encourage. We encourage them to ship fast, and learn, and make mistakes. It's a constant tension that we're navigating.
quotes.speaker: Paul Adams
quotes.context: Highlights the practical leadership challenge of balancing craft quality with speed-to-learn, framing it as an ongoing trade-off to manage rather than “solve.”

quotes.topic_title: AI as a meteor: hype skepticism vs all-in mindset
quotes.text: Ever since that day, I literally wake up every day thinking about AI pretty much.
quotes.speaker: Paul Adams
quotes.context: Captures the intensity and consistency required to build real AI intuition rather than treating it as a side project.

quotes.topic_title: AI as a meteor: hype skepticism vs all-in mindset
quotes.text: You're either all in, really truly all in. This is a meteor coming towards you. This is bigger than mobile as a technology shift, as big as the internet. Maybe it's bigger than the internet itself as a technology shift, the way it'll shape society.
quotes.speaker: Paul Adams
quotes.context: A memorable mental model (“meteor”) for prioritization and urgency in product strategy amid platform shifts.

quotes.topic_title: AI as a meteor: hype skepticism vs all-in mindset
quotes.text: And then, I think there's people in another camp, which is, "I've heard this before. It's hype. Last year was crypto. It was Web3. None of those things worked out. There was the metaverse."
quotes.speaker: Paul Adams
quotes.context: Explains a common organizational blocker—hype-cycle fatigue—and why teams may underreact to AI despite evidence.

quotes.topic_title: AI as a meteor: hype skepticism vs all-in mindset
quotes.text: I'm all in in the other camp. This is going to radically transform society and it blows my mind even seeing new types of things that come out, like ChatGPT Vision just came out recently, and just seeing the things that people can do with it. And we're just scratching the surface still.
quotes.speaker: Paul Adams
quotes.context: Uses a concrete example (ChatGPT Vision) to argue the tech is early and expanding, supporting an “all-in” strategy.

quotes.topic_title: How to get started: make time, read, and try tools
quotes.text: You just have to take the time. There's just no other way for me.
quotes.speaker: Paul Adams
quotes.context: A blunt prioritization principle: meaningful AI learning requires protected time, not passive awareness.

quotes.topic_title: How to get started: make time, read, and try tools
quotes.text: It's about priorities. It doesn't mean that you need to work crazy hours. I don't believe in working crazy hours.
quotes.speaker: Paul Adams
quotes.context: Reframes “keeping up with AI” as a prioritization problem rather than a hustle/overwork mandate.

quotes.topic_title: How to get started: make time, read, and try tools
quotes.text: Reading is the thing. You got to read. You got to stay up to date, and you got to play with things, and try things.
quotes.speaker: Paul Adams
quotes.context: A simple operating system for getting started: continuous learning plus hands-on experimentation.

quotes.topic_title: How to get started: make time, read, and try tools
quotes.text: And, I took some photos of her food. And, you can do all sorts of crazy stuff, like tell you how healthy the meal is or whatever.
quotes.speaker: Paul Adams
quotes.context: Concrete example of low-friction experimentation (ChatGPT Vision) to build intuition about capabilities.

quotes.topic_title: How to get started: make time, read, and try tools
quotes.text: So, my advice people is, you've got to try it. You've got to set aside the time, or it'll pass you by.
quotes.speaker: Paul Adams
quotes.context: A warning and call-to-action: without deliberate practice, leaders risk missing the wave entirely.

quotes.topic_title: Don’t force AI mockups; think strategically instead
quotes.text: ... Yeah, a lot of the tech is invisible.
quotes.speaker: Paul Adams
quotes.context: Reframes AI as often being backend infrastructure, cautioning leaders against forcing superficial AI features into designs.

quotes.topic_title: Don’t force AI mockups; think strategically instead
quotes.text: But, it's funny, even if you go back 18 months, I think if I was on your podcast 18 months ago and you said to me like, "Hey, what do you think about AI?" I would've said something like, "It's not real. Machine learning's real, let's talk about that."
quotes.speaker: Paul Adams
quotes.context: Highlights how fast the AI landscape and leaders’ mental models can shift, implying teams should stay adaptable rather than dogmatic.

quotes.topic_title: Don’t force AI mockups; think strategically instead
quotes.text: But a lot of the improvements are behind the scenes. They're with large language models or different types of things people are building in the background of infrastructure.
quotes.speaker: Paul Adams
quotes.context: Actionable reminder to look for leverage in infrastructure and core capabilities, not just UI-level AI “mockups.”

quotes.topic_title: Don’t force AI mockups; think strategically instead
quotes.text: But I do think that people need to start really thinking strategically.
quotes.speaker: Paul Adams
quotes.context: Directs practitioners to shift from feature-level AI thinking to strategy-level product implications.

quotes.topic_title: Don’t force AI mockups; think strategically instead
quotes.text: And if so, for some I think they require a foundational strategic change. Others, it might be less so.
quotes.speaker: Paul Adams
quotes.context: Provides a practical segmentation lens: some products need deep strategy resets for AI, while others only need incremental adjustments.

quotes.topic_title: Framework: map your product’s core job to AI capabilities
quotes.text: I wouldn't start there. I'd start with the thing your product does. What's the core premise behind it? Why do people use it? What problem does it solve for them? That kind of thing.
quotes.speaker: Paul Adams
quotes.context: A first-principles reminder to anchor AI strategy in the product’s core job rather than the novelty of new tech.

quotes.topic_title: Framework: map your product’s core job to AI capabilities
quotes.text: So go back to basics. "Okay, what is my product for? And why do people love it?' And then ask, "Can AI do that?"
quotes.speaker: Paul Adams
quotes.context: A simple, repeatable diagnostic question teams can use to evaluate AI disruption or opportunity for any product capability.

quotes.topic_title: Framework: map your product’s core job to AI capabilities
quotes.text: So you're going to need to map what your product does against what AI can do.
quotes.speaker: Paul Adams
quotes.context: A clear methodology: create a capability-by-capability mapping between your product’s value and AI’s current/near-term abilities.

quotes.topic_title: Framework: map your product’s core job to AI capabilities
quotes.text: And then, for some of it'll be replacement. AI would replace, it'll just do it. And, in other places it'll be augmentation. It'll augment. It'll help people as the copilot ideas that are going around.
quotes.speaker: Paul Adams
quotes.context: A practical lens for product planning: decide where AI should fully automate versus where it should assist users.

quotes.topic_title: Framework: map your product’s core job to AI capabilities
quotes.text: But yeah, I think that you've got to map your product, and what AI can do, and what it will be able to do, and then ask yourself, "Okay, what are we going to do?"
quotes.speaker: Paul Adams
quotes.context: Emphasizes that the mapping exercise must include near-future AI capabilities and culminate in concrete strategic decisions.

quotes.topic_title: Intercom’s post-ChatGPT strategy reset and building Fin
quotes.text: This is it. This is the time. This is the moment. This is the before after.
quotes.speaker: Paul Adams
quotes.context: A memorable “before/after moment” framework for recognizing inflection points that justify major strategic change.

quotes.topic_title: Intercom’s post-ChatGPT strategy reset and building Fin
quotes.text: So, we literally ripped up our strategy almost entirely, and started again, from first principles and said, "Okay, why do people use Intercom?"
quotes.speaker: Paul Adams
quotes.context: A concrete methodology: reset the roadmap and rebuild strategy from first principles when a platform shift changes what’s possible.

quotes.topic_title: Intercom’s post-ChatGPT strategy reset and building Fin
quotes.text: So we did. We totally changed how we think, how we work, and we just went heads down and built a product called Fin.
quotes.speaker: Paul Adams
quotes.context: An execution lesson: strategy resets must translate into operating-model change and focused building, not just new positioning.

quotes.topic_title: Intercom’s post-ChatGPT strategy reset and building Fin
quotes.text: So the first line of defense for a customer support team is Finn, not a person.
quotes.speaker: Paul Adams
quotes.context: A counterintuitive product/ops shift: design support as “AI-first” rather than “human-first with automation on the side.”

quotes.topic_title: Intercom’s post-ChatGPT strategy reset and building Fin
quotes.text: The tech is way ahead. It's actually people wrapping their heads around what this means for the role, the teams, loads of cool stuff, like new types of jobs for people, like conversation designers, a job we have where you design the conversations that Fin does or managers.
quotes.speaker: Paul Adams
quotes.context: A practical organizational insight: the bottleneck is change management and new roles, not model capability.

quotes.topic_title: Early results: adoption, skepticism, and organizational change
quotes.text: It's very early, honestly, to be able to answer that properly. And it depends what you measure as success.
quotes.speaker: Paul Adams
quotes.context: A practical reminder to define success metrics up front—especially in hyped markets where “interest” can be mistaken for real impact.

quotes.topic_title: Early results: adoption, skepticism, and organizational change
quotes.text: So, if you're measuring it by interest, it's a huge success.
quotes.speaker: Paul Adams
quotes.context: Highlights a counterintuitive pitfall: early AI wins may be demand/curiosity rather than durable product value.

quotes.topic_title: Early results: adoption, skepticism, and organizational change
quotes.text: We have some customers who are hugely successful with it. They can answer up to 50, 60, 70% of their inbound questions with Fin.
quotes.speaker: Paul Adams
quotes.context: A concrete benchmark practitioners can use to gauge what “good” early AI support automation can look like in production.

quotes.topic_title: Early results: adoption, skepticism, and organizational change
quotes.text: If you think of AI Intercom as, I guess, a new startup, even though we're 900 people, the growth curve, you're looking for this exponential curve, as opposed to big public company linear growth curve.
quotes.speaker: Paul Adams
quotes.context: A useful mental model for org change: treat an AI pivot like building a new startup inside the company with different growth expectations.

quotes.topic_title: Early results: adoption, skepticism, and organizational change
quotes.text: With the exponential one, it takes a while. The first year or two years is the bottom of that.
quotes.speaker: Paul Adams
quotes.context: Sets realistic timelines for AI-driven transformation—early periods can look flat even when the trajectory is promising.

quotes.topic_title: Mind-blowing AI capabilities and job transformation examples
quotes.text: The way our machine learning thing worked before ChatGPT was that there was not a manual setup. A customer support manager would have to orchestrate the bot, and teach it what to say, and just a lot of orchestration, a lot of teaching it. And then, ChatGPT showed up and it's like, "Oh, it can do it by itself."
quotes.speaker: Paul Adams
quotes.context: A concrete before/after example showing how LLMs can remove heavy configuration and orchestration work from AI product deployments.

quotes.topic_title: Mind-blowing AI capabilities and job transformation examples
quotes.text: And you're looking at this thing writing code and you're like, "What happens next? Do we need as many engineers or will their role change? And they'll start doing different types of things like reviewing code instead of writing code?"
quotes.speaker: Paul Adams
quotes.context: A practical reframing of how AI shifts team roles from production to oversight, implying new staffing and workflow models.

quotes.topic_title: Mind-blowing AI capabilities and job transformation examples
quotes.text: So, seven years to be a radiologist, and then you're just into the job. AI, it seems it's already better at it. So, it's already better at it, and it can ingest every X-ray ever made. No human can ever read, and think about, and synthesize every X-ray ever made.
quotes.speaker: Paul Adams
quotes.context: A vivid, domain-specific example illustrating why AI can surpass human expertise via scale of training data and synthesis.

quotes.topic_title: Mind-blowing AI capabilities and job transformation examples
quotes.text: Radiologists will not take x-ray. Well, I guess they might take them. But, they won't analyze them, for sure. They'll look at what AI says, check that it's right, and then it's bedside manner time.
quotes.speaker: Paul Adams
quotes.context: An actionable job-transformation model: AI does primary analysis while humans move to verification and high-trust communication.

quotes.topic_title: Mind-blowing AI capabilities and job transformation examples
quotes.text: Your voice would be translated in Spanish in real-time for me. It's, again, mind-blowing.
quotes.speaker: Paul Adams
quotes.context: A concrete product capability example that suggests new real-time, cross-language UX patterns for communication products.

quotes.topic_title: Team and org implications: ML investment and AI UX challenges
quotes.text: Ultimately, you need really great machine learning engineers. That's where it starts. And if you don't have that, then you're going to find it hard to build truly, really, truly great things.
quotes.speaker: Paul Adams
quotes.context: Sets a clear prerequisite for AI product success: invest in top-tier ML engineering capability before expecting differentiated outcomes.

quotes.topic_title: Team and org implications: ML investment and AI UX challenges
quotes.text: So, you need to invest in building out that function, I think. Really invest in building out the function.
quotes.speaker: Paul Adams
quotes.context: Actionable org guidance: treat ML as a core function that needs sustained resourcing, not a side project.

quotes.topic_title: Team and org implications: ML investment and AI UX challenges
quotes.text: Our ML team's way bigger than it was and way bigger than it ever has been at Intercom.
quotes.speaker: Paul Adams
quotes.context: Concrete example of how AI shifts org structure—ML capacity expands materially to support product execution.

quotes.topic_title: Team and org implications: ML investment and AI UX challenges
quotes.text: What happens when there's now an AI assistant in there? How do they talk? And what do they do? And when do they interject? And how do you represent that in the user experience that feels natural? So that's a really hard design problem.
quotes.speaker: Paul Adams
quotes.context: Highlights the key AI UX challenge: designing human+AI collaboration and turn-taking inside existing workflows.

quotes.topic_title: Team and org implications: ML investment and AI UX challenges
quotes.text: I think a second thing that comes to mind is not to think about it as bolted on. I think some people are still in that camp.
quotes.speaker: Paul Adams
quotes.context: Counter to the “AI team adds AI” approach—AI should be integrated into how product teams work and build.

quotes.topic_title: Staying current: sources, tools, and experimentation habits
quotes.text: Yeah, what I've mentioned so far, don't bolt it on. Stay up-to-date. I mentioned earlier, read, read. I feel like I'm behind all the time. It's moving so fast.
quotes.speaker: Paul Adams
quotes.context: Concise guidance on avoiding superficial AI adoption and building a habit of continuous learning given the pace of change.

quotes.topic_title: Staying current: sources, tools, and experimentation habits
quotes.text: I actually use the recommended feed in Twitter a lot. I think, because I interact and look at a lot of AI, I get to see a lot more. So I do that and I do it deliberately to try and generate more stuff.
quotes.speaker: Paul Adams
quotes.context: A practical tactic for “training” your information inputs so discovery algorithms surface more relevant AI updates.

quotes.topic_title: Staying current: sources, tools, and experimentation habits
quotes.text: You just try. Try book out half an hour and just go deep for half an hour, and then bookmark a few things, come back to them. Like everyone, you could be so busy, so many distractions, you just got to have to set aside time.
quotes.speaker: Paul Adams
quotes.context: A lightweight experimentation routine (timebox + bookmarking) that’s easy to apply even with a busy schedule.

quotes.topic_title: Staying current: sources, tools, and experimentation habits
quotes.text: And, you got to try these things to understand whether it's any good, or useful, or where's the boundaries, and how does it work, and so on.
quotes.speaker: Paul Adams
quotes.context: Emphasizes hands-on testing as the fastest way to learn tool capabilities and limitations rather than relying on secondhand opinions.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: HelpBar solves this, it delivers answers directly inside your app and eliminates context switching.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: A clear product strategy principle: reduce user friction by bringing help to the point of need inside the workflow.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: Users can search or ask questions to get AI generated answers and lists of the most relevant documentation from all of your help sources, including your knowledge base, docs, blog, and video libraries.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: A concrete methodology for AI support: unify disparate content sources into a single retrieval + generation experience.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: You can also use HelpBar to navigate your app and launch actions, such as scheduling a meeting or viewing an interactive demo.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: Highlights an actionable pattern: turn search from “find info” into “complete tasks” via in-app actions.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: The best products today use Command K for in-app search and navigation.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: A memorable benchmark suggesting a modern UX standard practitioners can adopt for discoverability and speed.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: HelpBar makes that readily available within your app without engineering or new code.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: A specific implementation claim: shipping meaningful UX improvements without engineering investment.

quotes.topic_title: Internal buy-in, ambiguity, and horizon planning for AI
quotes.text: Also, no one knows. No one knows.
quotes.speaker: Paul Adams
quotes.context: A blunt reminder that AI strategy decisions are being made under extreme uncertainty, so teams must plan and execute without false certainty.

quotes.topic_title: Internal buy-in, ambiguity, and horizon planning for AI
quotes.text: But equally, some of the hurdles have been like, "Why are you all in?" And I'm like, "An educated guess. A hunch."
quotes.speaker: Paul Adams
quotes.context: Highlights that leadership conviction in ambiguous environments often rests on informed judgment rather than provable ROI, which is useful for internal buy-in conversations.

quotes.topic_title: Internal buy-in, ambiguity, and horizon planning for AI
quotes.text: The part of business strategy and product strategy that, it's just hard. It's like taste.
quotes.speaker: Paul Adams
quotes.context: Frames strategy as a “taste”-like capability—hard to quantify, but built through experience—helping practitioners justify why debates won’t be settled by analysis alone.

quotes.topic_title: Internal buy-in, ambiguity, and horizon planning for AI
quotes.text: We're in Horizon 1 land. We're like, "Yeah, and the next year we're going to do this." And he's like, "Yeah, but two years from now, if this path plays out, everything we're doing now is going to be irrelevant and useless."
quotes.speaker: Paul Adams
quotes.context: A concrete horizon-planning tension: near-term roadmaps may be rational yet still become obsolete quickly, pushing teams to balance execution with future disruption risk.

quotes.topic_title: Internal buy-in, ambiguity, and horizon planning for AI
quotes.text: So, a lot of the challenges have been navigating that ambiguity and helping people get the conviction I have without drying out voices of alternative voices and opinions, which are often valid too.
quotes.speaker: Paul Adams
quotes.context: Actionable leadership guidance: build conviction while preserving dissent, especially when the environment is uncertain and alternative views may be correct.

quotes.topic_title: Where AI disrupts next: reporting and project management examples
quotes.text: Yeah, showing people is definitely the easiest way.
quotes.speaker: Paul Adams
quotes.context: Practical go-to tactic for building internal conviction: demo concrete AI capabilities rather than relying on abstract arguments.

quotes.topic_title: Where AI disrupts next: reporting and project management examples
quotes.text: Adapt or die is our mantra. Adapt or die.
quotes.speaker: Paul Adams
quotes.context: A crisp strategic posture for teams in AI-exposed markets: treat AI adoption as existential, not optional.

quotes.topic_title: Where AI disrupts next: reporting and project management examples
quotes.text: Maybe that's all done dead now. And, the reporting product of the future is just a box, and the box just goes to the database, and the box is just, "Who was our best salesman last year January? Okay. Who was our top performing representative in January? Lenny."
quotes.speaker: Paul Adams
quotes.context: Contrarian product thesis with a concrete example: AI may collapse complex analytics UIs into a simple conversational query interface.

quotes.topic_title: Where AI disrupts next: reporting and project management examples
quotes.text: And yet, equally ripe for a newcomer to come with a completely different paradigm and potentially take over.
quotes.speaker: Paul Adams
quotes.context: Strategic warning/opportunity: adjacent categories like reporting and project management may be vulnerable to AI-native entrants with new interaction models.

quotes.topic_title: Where AI disrupts next: reporting and project management examples
quotes.text: Think about what problem are you solving as a company.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: A reusable lens for AI strategy: anchor decisions in the underlying job-to-be-done rather than the current product/UI implementation.
